newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-BOSNICH FINED OVER HITLER-STYLE SALUTE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BOSNICH FINED OVER HITLER-STYLE SALUTE.

text.p: Aston Villa goalkeeper Mark Bosnich, at the centre of a storm after making a Hitler-style salute to Tottenham fans in a recent match, was found guilty of misconduct by the English Football Association on Friday and fined 1,000 pounds ( $1,660).
The Australian keeper was also severely censured, warned as to his future conduct and ordered to pay the costs of the F.A. Commission hearing.
Announcing the decision, F.A. spokesman Steve Double said: "The Comission heard that Bosnich had been subjected to abusive chanting from the home crowd before the incident in the 48th minute.

"Bosnich told the Commission that his gesture to the crowd was intended as a Basil Fawlty-style joke. He was unaware of Tottenham's Jewish following and was devastated at the reaction to the incident."
Double added: "He stated that he abhorred racism. The Commission decided that, while Bosnich's action was an act of stupidity, it was not his intention to cause offence or be insulting.
Villa manager Brian Little emerged from the hour and a half meeting satisfied with the outcome. He said: "It has been a fair hearing."
Bosnich was relieved with the outcome of the hearing, saying: "What we have seen today is commonsense prevail. Let's hope I can now put this incident behind me and go forward with my career."

Asked about the fine imposed by the Commission, he said: "It's time to put this behind me there are far more important things going on than this case and to be honest I'm sick of hearing my own voice."
The outcome will come as a relief to the 24-year-old player who could have been suspended. But he is still waiting to hear if he will face police action over the gesture.
